title: How to Prepare for a Photographic Trip

steps.headline: Bring a camera or cameras.
steps.description: If at all possible, it is a good idea to have a backup. If you have some type of mechanical or power failure, you will not be able to take any pictures without a backup.

steps.headline: Be sure that you have a flash or a strobe.
steps.description: Your camera may have that and if you are used to using that on camera flash, then use it. If you believe that you need the strobe for the effects that you want, then be sure to bring that.

steps.headline: Have film and/or memory cards.
steps.description: Having to buy those supplies may be a difficult proposition in an unfamiliar locale.

steps.headline: Bring filters.
steps.description: Depending on the location, you can decide ahead of time which ones to bring.

steps.headline: Consider bring a light meter.
steps.description: Your camera might have one internally or you may not even use one. If you do, put some thought into if you will need it. It is, potentially, one more piece to lose.

steps.headline: Be sure to pack batteries and make sure of the types of batteries your different pieces may need.
Have a digital card reader.
steps.description: This is an easy way of getting pictures out of your camera.

steps.headline: Take some form of tripod.
steps.description: There are small tripods that will fit in your luggage, monopods, or something that will help hold your camera steady.

steps.headline: Consider a place to offload your memory cards.
steps.description: If you bring a digital camera, it is very handy to be able to upload the pictures to something so that you can take even more.

steps.headline: Plan ahead of time if you want to share your images on the Internet.
steps.description: That way you can set it up ahead of time. Also, you will want to investigate if that is even a viable option for your destination.

steps.headline: Always be aware of the risk of theft and prepare accordingly.
